awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Increase the Throughput of Non-Relational Databases through Theoretical Modeling and Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
The explosive growth of data is driving the rapid evolution of massive data-storage systems.  These systems are widely used, not only in large-scale Internet services, but also in scientific projects in diverse areas such as astronomy, geography, and genetics.  This project will increase the efficiency of these data-storage systems, which will allow processing more data at lower cost. There is the potential for a large societal impact as science and engineering research is made more cost-effective.

More specifically, this project will work on improving non-relational databases with log-structured merge-tree storage architectures.  One main focus will be on improving a key component of such systems, namely, compaction policies.  Compaction policies are not yet well understood, but are crucial for system performance.  To date, compaction policies have been designed by trial and error, guided mainly by empirical experience.  The project will develop analytical models for compaction, validate and refine the models with empirical testing, design improved policies that are optimal according to the models, and deploy these policies in live systems.  Further, the developed theoretical models will be leveraged to optimize non-relational database systems in handling high volumes of dynamic continuous queries, which arrive and expire rapidly.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project studied how to increase the performance of NoSQL database systems, which are a popular type of database systems used to store large amounts of data. Specifically, this project studied how to optimize the compaction process in NoSQL databases, which is the process used to periodically reorganize the stored data to facilitate fast query response times.  Previous work mostly relied on heuristics, whereas this project proposed theoretically optimal algorithms. The proposed compaction algorithms were implemented on existing database systems and were shown to outperform the state-of-the-art. The project also studied how to best index multi-dimensional data, such as spatial data, on NoSQL databases to facilitate both fast insertion and query times.

Seven undergraduate students were supported by this project. These students were involved in the research process, and were trained on NoSQL storage principles and experimental setup. Two PhD students graduated. The developed compaction algorithms are being used in the AsterixDB NoSQL database system, which is an Apache open source system. Optimizing the management of big data may cut the storage costs and the energy consumption in data centers and  allow users to manage more data with the existing hardware infrastructure, which is critical given the new wave of sensors and the Internet-of-Things.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2021
Modified by: Neal E Young
